title: 106_hr3657
content: LAND CONVEYANCE AND SETTLEMENT, SAN BERNARDINO NATIONAL FOREST, CALIFORNIA. The Secretary of Agriculture will convey approximately 1.06 acres of real property in the San Bernardino National Forest to KATY 101.3 FM. The legal description will be prepared by mutual agreement, and the consideration will be based on the appraised fair market value. The Secretary will release KATY from claims for $16,600. Access over National Forest System lands is not required for the conveyed property. (f) Administrative Costs.--Costs related to creating a subdivided parcel, survey recordation, zoning, and planning approval for the conveyance by KATY must be covered by KATY. (g) Assumption of Liability.--KATY, by accepting the conveyance, agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the United States, General Telephone and Electronics Corporation (GTE), and any third parties associated with the parcel. (h) Treatment of Receipts.--All funds received from this conveyance will be deposited into the established fund under Public Law 90- The funds from this section will be deposited in the fund established under Public Law 90-171 (16 U.S.C. 484a; commonly known as the Sisk Act) for the acquisition of lands, waters, and interests in land for the San Bernardino National Forest. Amendments are made to the Receipts Act to allow for this. Amendments are made to the Receipts Act to allocate twelve and one-half percent of funds to be used for National Forest System purposes in San Bernardino, Cleveland, and Los Angeles counties. SEC. 2. SANTA ROSA AND SAN JACINTO MOUNTAINS NATIONAL MONUMENT CLARIFYING AMENDMENTS. Amendments to the Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument Act of 2000 include removing references to specific committees, clarifying language regarding the Act, and ensuring that Wilderness areas within the monument remain subject to existing laws. The Santo Domingo Pueblo Claims Settlement Act of 2000 is amended by adding a technical correction at the end, including miscellaneous provisions in Section 7. The Secretary must acquire New Mexico trust lands in a specific location within 2 years by exchange, including mineral and water rights. Unappropriated public lands in New Mexico can be used for the exchange. The exchanged lands must be of equal value, with adjustments made as necessary. Upon acquisition of lands under the Act, the Secretary shall convey all title to the Pueblo, who may then convey the land back to the Secretary for trust purposes. The Pueblo can also exchange restricted lands for other lands to further the Act's purposes. Any land exchange agreements between the Pueblo and parties involved in a specific legal action must be approved by December 31, 2001. The Pueblo can convey acquired lands to the Secretary for trust purposes. Resolutions 97-010 and C22 are authorized for certain agreements, transactions, and conveyances. The Tribal Council of the Pueblo de Cochiti and the Pueblo of Santo Domingo have approved boundary dispute resolutions, including Cochiti's agreement to relinquish claim to overlapping lands with Santo Domingo and disclaim any compensation rights. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
